did.unittitle: National Association of Real Estate Boards, Build America Better Committee Scrapbook Collection

repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

did.abstract: F. Lawrence Dow, of Hartford, Connecticut, served as chairman of the NAREB's Build America Better Committee. The Committee worked in the field of neighborhood conservation and rehabilitation. The collection consists of two scrapbooks (1961-1962) containing fliers and newspaper clippings documenting the committee's work.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The National Association of Real Estate Exchanges was established on May 12, 1908, at the YMCA Auditorium in Chicago, IL. With 120 founding members, 19 Boards, and one State Association, the National Association of Real Estate Exchanges' objective was "to unite the real estate men of America for the purpose of effectively exerting a combined influence upon matters affecting real estate interests." In 1916, the National Association of Real Estate Exchange's name was changed to The National Association of Real Estate Boards ( NAREB). In 1972, the name of the National Association of Real Estate Boards was changed to the National Association of Realtors速 ( NAR). The Association became the largest trade association in the United States in the early 1970s, with over 400,000 members. Today, the National Association of Realtors速 has over 1.2 million members, 54 State Associations (including Guam, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands) and more than 1,400 local Associations. This and additional details about the organization can be found on their website.

In 1952, the Build America Better Committee began as a program with the focus on re-energizing run-down neighborhoods. The program's name was changed to Realtor速 Week in 1956, to distinguish Realtors速 from non-members, and to highlight the right to own property as one of the cornerstones of democracy. In 1975, the name was changed to Private Property Week, in order to promote the basic human and constitutional right to own, use and transfer property. In 1986, the name was changed to American Home Week, celebrating the constitutional right to own private property, and home ownership. From 2002 to 2008, National Homeownership Month was created to celebrate homeownership across the country. This information and more is available on the NAR website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of two scrapbooks (1961-1962) containing fliers and newspaper clippings documenting the committee's work.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], National Association of Real Estate Boards, Build America Better Committee Scrapbook Collection. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The scrapbooks are presumed to have been donated by Mr. Dow.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of materials pertaining to to a variety of Connecticut-based organizations. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the Reading Room desk.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research.
